title: Prusa / Printrbot generic z axis coupler

description.text:
coupler that works with 5mm stepper motors, when the 5/16 threaded rod is double nutted. Hex hole is slightly bigger than a 5/16 nut, re-print hole bigger and fill with silicone if backlash is an issue for you.

Now with new version 3 that has two setscrews, Version 4 is two parts

Print the v4 coupler, then print a 5/16 nutcap.  Put a piece of tape over the shaft hole of the coupler (or insert the stepper motor).  Squirt some silicone into the coupler and set the nutcap in the hexhole.  Let set-up as directed on the tube of silicone.  Insert m4 nut, then m4 set screw to coupler.  Then put 2 nuts on the end of your threaded rod, tightened against eachother.  Use a 608 bearing holder if you have a prusa, my printrbot has gravity on it's side.
SCAD file only work in the prusa folder, unless you change out the variables

comments.text: I'm trying to use newcouplerv4.scad and it calls for configuration.scad, which is not included in the Thing Files. I'm wondering if this is why newcouplerv4.scad is not rendering properly for me in OpenSCAD (It's not projecting the threaded rod shaft). Could you please reupload a correct set of SCAD files? Thanks.

I made this iPad keyguard for a student who needed to use a very basic yes/no choice app. He has poor motor control so the boxes allow him to choose only one thing at a time and the fin in the center blocks his hand from moving to the next box.  This particular version fits inside his iPad case and we velcro it to the sides. The app is called YES/NO by Answers HD. I am NOT affiliated with them in any way, just found it in an app search. Let me know if you know of a good app to choose from a field of 2-4! (disability, assistive technology, adaptive equipment)

description.text: This is a Python script for FreeCAD which generates parametric project enclosure boxes. All the dimensions and various other features of the box are completely configurable. Source also available on gist: https://gist.github.com/1361643

Save the ProjectEnclosure.py file to your FreeCAD macros directory.  
From the FreeCAD interface, you can use the "Tools -> Macros..." menu to view or change your macro directory.  Once the macro is in place, you can execute the macro from the same dialog.  
This script is implemented as a FreeCAD Python Feature which means that you can edit all the parameters from the FreeCAD gui without touching any Python code at all.  Select the box, and click on the "Data" tab in the left pane to see and edit any of the parameters.   One of the screenshots shows an example of this.

I created a bookmark using tinkercad. It has a length of 80 mm, and width of 20 mm, and a height of 3 mm.

Printer:

Micro 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No
How I Designed This First I started with a basic cube. I stretched it out until it had a length of 80mm. Then I changed the height to 3mm. Then I was finished.

Objectives Students will be expected to learn how to do volume and area in math, as well as learn how to use Tinkercad. Audiences This project is aimed towards kids in grades 4 and up. Preparation The only things necessary for this project are Tinkercad accounts and a 3D printer. Steps! First the teacher will tell the students to add a cube to the bed. Then they will tell them to stretch the bookmark as big as they want (as long as it fits on the print bed) as well as the height. Next, once the bookmarks are printed, the teacher will tell the students to find the area and volume of the bookmark. The students will then know how to do both volume and area and they will remember it because they had fun. Then the students can use the bookmarks for reading. Results The students should have learned the basics of Tinkercad as well as how to find the area and volume of an object.

This is a air horn that I designed a while back, but i haven't got a chance to print it print yet. You will have to use a balloon in the back of the body in the horn body to produce the sound. When you print off all the tubes standing up so they will turn out more circular. To put the air horn together you will have to print off all the parts, then you will have to cut a circle out of the balloon and stretch it over the end of the the main body. You will then have to screw on the cap, until it is screwed all the way on. Then you will insert the tube the tube true the hole at the top until you can see the shape of the tube threw the balloon. You may have to sand down the outside of the tube to make it fit in the hole, but you want too still be tight to the sides of the top hole, to make a seal. Finely you insert the horn bell on the end of the tube, and glue it in place.

title: Moving Extrudate Cooler (for Prusa i3 with Diamond Hotend)

description.text:
So here is my first Thing... This moving extrudate cooler is designed in FreeCAD to fit on the X-axis bars of a Prusa i3. The X carriage drags it along the bars, allowing it to move 20mm left and right.
This makes that the mouth of the funnel (30mm) is mostly behind the extruder for optimal cooling of the part of your print that was just extruded.
And it's mounted on the back, so it never blocks your view. The Fan duct was derived from thehans' design and reworked in FreeCAD, completely parameterised so you can adjust it to your needs.
The other files are dimensioned to fit on my Prusa with a Diamond Hotend, but can be easily adjusted to fit almost any printer with a similar X carriage design.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Notes: I printed the funnel in PLA a bit colder on 165°, gives me better bridges. You'll need to rotate the base and the funnel before printing, I left them the way they are generated by FreeCAD. The funnel will generate a warning in Repetier Host. Ignore it, Slic3r doesn't have a problem with it, and it prints normally.

All mounting holes are made for 3,5 mm regular self-tapping parkerscrews. 8x 12mm to mount the Base over the rods using the top and bottom Axis Supports
6x 20mm to mount the Fansupport on the Base with the spacers in between, and the fan to the Fansupport. Funnel fits on a 5015 fan.
FreeCAD and plenty of good coffee.

Part idealized to "lift" a little table , preventing touch the smooth rods , bearings come under pressure , I recommend you use horizontal compensation -0.2 if the holes in your table do not correspond to the distance of the holes of the bearings I recommend you do the drilling on the table.

UPDATED: 03/14/2016 - LED parts file modified (Made LED holder 1mm shorter so top cover won't push against it). Not exactly the shape of a Batarang but its close....admit it.
This 75mm Micro fly's like a beast, I have about 25 mins of flight already on it, I get about 5-7 mins of flight with a 240mah battery.
Currently I'm using a full Hubsanx4 setup, FC, 7mm motors, props(i had to cut them down to 49mm). I designed this to be used with either a hubsan FC, micro scisky, Micro MWC or a Nano QX.
I am currently still working on fitting a FPV setup on this bad boy.
I've flown and crashed this micro a bunch of times and the motors never popped out of the mount, like i thought they would.
Grab a super bright 3mm LED and stuff it into Bat signal lamp and go fly and have fun ! Suggested Parts list:
7mm motors-you can find these on banggood or MMW...your pick
Props-http://www.banggood.com/5-PCS-HM830-RC-Paper-Plane-Blade-Replacement-p-916674.html
FC-Hobby King for Micro MWC or Banggood for Micro Scisky
Battery-I'd go with nano tech-check ebay ! Have any questions? ask away! Download, Build, Fly and Share !
Follow on Instagram for weekly designs @3dprint_rckc

description.text:
Update to my Kossel Mini Carriage http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:627955.
Added more bulk to belt clips and "horns" for more strength. It uses belt clip design by incorporating a reoriented JC Doll's GT2 Belt Clip - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:117987 You can cut all three open belts to uniform length and install it as if it were a closed belt. No zip ties, no clamps. OpenSCAD file included but you have to get the other support files from Johann's github repository - https://github.com/jcrocholl/kossel Thanks, Johann Rocholl and JC Doll, for sharing your designs.

This project should be graded on how nice it comes out looking. Maybe try to make cookies with it too for extra credit. In the end, it should just be a fun intermediate experience that makes you want to continue pursuing the art of 3d printing.

Printer:

M3D Micro

Use your software to make the basic shape of what you want. Then, use the offset tool to make the same shape surrounding it. Step 2 Extrude the drawing out to the desired distance. Step 3 Put a lip around the top, so it is easier to press down. Get your file ready to print, by exporting it into the print software. Print it. Final Step Bake Cookies

Project: Cookie Cutter Objective- gain a basic understanding of 3d printing.
Audience- Recommended for beginners.
Preparation- Learn as you go.
Steps- Listed above.
Result- A better understanding of 3d printing, plus a cookie cutter.
This is a 100 mm long, 65 mm wide mold for agarose gels. Very similar to some of the older models, but cheaper to buy

Adapters for mounting J-head (V5,V6) extruders onto my G2S Universal Effector (spider). http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1356159 For a single extruder, you can use the cooling fan attached to the extruder's fins (third photo). There isn't room for two fans, so dual extruder configurations will require using a single fan mounted onto the spider instead. The 30mm fan duct (shown) works, but the heat sink fins do run a bit warm, so I've designed a 40mm solution. [http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1381000] There are separate adapters for V5 or V6 extruders, print whichever one you need. I apologize for having the adapter mounting nuts located below the platform, making installation more difficult than I would have liked. But I have added sufficient extra material around these nuts so they can be made captive by folding a bit of plastic down with a hot soldering iron to lock the nuts into place (fourth photo). Update: Design finalized and tested.

Printer:

Geeetech Delta G2S Pro

No

No

30%

description.text: This is based off the excellent mech by NathansMind. I rescaled it for 15mm play and broke it into pieces to make printing easier at such a small size. It's about the size of a "dreadnought". I typically print it all in one print with all the pieces laid out as they are with support. Then I clean off the support and assemble it with super glue. I have also made some great "bits bots" using the legs from this model and the torso/weapons from what ever spare parts I have laying around in my bits box. An all around great model! Note: example.stl is not intended to be printed. It is just for reference.

description.text:
This is a chalk holder made to resemble a lightsaber. The chalk goes where the laser blade should be and the knob holds it by means of a screw. 
You may use color chalks to make it more realistic.

Print both parts and join them with a screw. 
I recommend to download the source code and look for a parameter called 'screw', and 'r_screw' for the knob, since those are the values for the diameter of the screw that is going to be used. By default both are 3 mm.

author: Comssam

description.text: This is a cross platform program to create lithophanes of arbitrary size from digital pictures. A sample lithophane object is included. Most recent change is code to filter the image to reduce the probability of failed extrusion. Older changes from previous include fixing a minor bug (one row of vertices was off by a "row") and initial implementation of OpenGL preview (it isn't very good at present).

This uses PySide so Python and Qt are required. They are probably already present on linux and if not the appropriate package manager should be used. To install for Windows or OS X:
  • download and install the appropriate binary for pyside
  • make sure the appropriate version of Python is installed
  • extract the archive for lithophane

    Create Lithophane Object

    Running the application opens a window. Open an image, most any image file will do thanks to Qt, and start setting parameters. On a replicator 2 the limit in resolution appears to be about 50 ppi (the pixels per inch is reported in the GUI). I find that 25 ppi is sufficient to produce satisfactory results. When satisfied, click the "Save" button in the toolbar -- this will create an object file in the same directory as the image was loaded from.

    Print Lithophane

    Load the object file. Currently only obj file format is created, Netfabb can be used to convert to STL if needed. If extra back thickness was set it will need to be moved to the platform. Set shells to 1 and fill to 100%. Use the desired layer thickness and print. Caution: when I've tried slicing for print on a Stratasys anything at background level was removed leaving holes in the model to be printed. I've never encountered a problem with Makerware, but make sure to review before printing.
    The provided lithophane profile is a default changing only the fill type to linear and the fill amount to 100%. This is only for Makerware after the change to hexagon fill and before a fix for 100% fill. Certainly in Makerware 2.4 it is no longer relevant.

    Other Thoughts

    The program works, but is definitely a work in progress and the code is embarrassingly ugly. My printing issues seem to have largely been sorted out and I've printed several 5x7 lithophanes at 0.10mm.
    Features that simply haven't been implemented yet include:

  • provision for a generating a ring to support hanging the lithophane
  • ability to crop the image
  • generate cylindrical lithophanes
  • generate cylindrical (coin) lithophanes
  • ...and others as documented in the bundled documentation

description.text:
An ECG machine is a common piece of equipment in hospitals, giving doctors a visual trace of the electrical signals from a patient's heart. To read these signals, sensors are attached to the patients's ankles and wrists using an ECG limb lead, which uses a plastic clamp to secure the sensor to the desired part of the body. 
This part had been printed and tested in Nepal, where a group of doctors were becoming frustrated with a poor design of ECG limb lead, where the plastic clamp kept falling apart. This was due to a connector between the two halves of the clamp which did not fit correctly. Here is our improved design, which forms a very snug fit. 
Thank you to Humanitarian Makers, Tho X. Bui and Ross Michaels, for their contributions to this design.

This is an EVA Extruder based on a wade plastic extruder and that use a hot glue gun heater and his 12mm diameter stick (8mm on study).
It fits instead of a wade extruder on a prusa mendel.
With this I could extrude soft part made of EVA.
This design is still on modification, stay tuned.
<big >BE CAREFULL : the hot gun heater is plugged on 220V, prefer using your hot-end heater/controller block.</big>

Print the extruder, the idler and the supporting plate.
open and cut a cheap 12mm glue gun body made of nylon.
drill an tape the hotend to be able to put a brass M6 drilled thread.
put an hot-end nozzle on it.
assemble everything and run.

title: eMAKER Huxley Remixed Bowden Extruder for use with E3D V6

description.text: This extruder part was remixed in order to support the official E3D V6 Lite Bowden extruder 1.75 fitting. This part was required because the original eMAKER Huxley only permitted a 2.2mm PTFE tube. E3D ships with a 4.2mm tube. We purchased the hardware from Home Depot in the Pipe fitting section. The Part number was LFA-708. It was a 1/8FIP brass Cap. We drilled out the center to push the PTFE tube all the way to the hobbled bolt for better alignment and increased support for flexible filament. You will have to drill out the part on the brass fitting side to the hobbled bolt as well. (assuming you want to go with the extended PTFE option) We used a 11/64 standard size bit (~4.31mm). If possible use a drill press to ensure that it is straight. You may have to file down the stepper motor bracket a bit. we took the holes down about 2 mm to make sure the gears were not binding. If you hear a strange clicking sound its probably the stepper skipping because there is to much lateral torque on the driveshaft. (Catastrophic failure will ensue if you don't fix this IMMEDIATELY) We recommend printing our x axis mounting bracket (STILL UNDER DEVELOPMENT) for a complete solution for the eMAKER Huxley E3D Upgrade. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1350748 Print with support

author: xsivejeff

description.text:
[UPDATE 7-19-16: I now recommend using the Duet and RepRapFirmware instead of Repetier on Due. Suitable mount STLs have been added.] Introducing the Tesseract Delta! It's an entirely new concept in frame design for Delta printers. Yep, that's right, the frame is a cube tilted up on one corner. This provides proper Delta column alignment, with no triangles! That means it can be built with common metal 90 degree brackets for maximum parts availability and rigidity. A tesseract (or hypercube) is the mathematical extension of a cube into four dimensions. The tilted orientation and delta mechanics add a new dimension to the typical cube-frame 3D printer -- thus the name. Any standard Delta drivetrain will work in this frame, but the one used here is a new ball-bearing U-joint based design. It's rigid and long-lasting. Any typical hot end may be installed given a suitable effector mount, but the one used here is a new hybrid Bowden / Replicator 2 hot end. In addition to being significantly more compact than an E3Dv6 or ANY groovemount, It is all-metal and reliably prints anything from PLA to polycarbonate. The "special sauce" in the stepped-diameter thermal barrier design is well-proven in tens of thousands of printers around the world and is widely available via the Makerbot Rep1/2/2x aftermarket parts ecosystem. The Tesseract Delta Rev2 is uploaded here in the STLs and BOM. Rev1 is included in the source file in case anyone is interested. Detailed Rev1 build info: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/deltabot/tesseract/deltabot/iibYgiTxU5U/TxYUtlvLCgAJ 2-26-16: Initial upload of STLs, BOM, build photos
7-19-16: Added mount STLs for Duet and PanelDue (4.3" v1.0) touchscreen.
4-10-17: Added "blank" effector STL for cutting out alternative hot ends mounts.

description.text: Originally designed by Frank Lloyd Wright in 1907 for the Avery Coonley House. This is adapted from Opportunities' STL. I imported it into Sketchup, and intersected the geometry with a plane to get a clean 2 dimensional shape without the triangulation artifacts from the STL file. There are 4 files total, two each for front and back of the plastic or glass substrate. If you don't want to do front and back, just print the front alone and scale the z independently for more or less relief. The largest two files are just large enough to fit on an Ultimaker bed.

This stained glass look was somewhat tedious to do, and required a lot of trial and error on my part. It was made from a piece of clear antiglare acrylic cut to size, and has PLA glued to each side. I found some colored gels on Amazon and cut each one to size, and used a soldering iron on low power to melt each gel into one side of the PLA. The PLA panels were fixed to the acrylic using the "5 second fix" UV cured resin. This worked better than the superglue I tried before, because i could reposition the PLA for perfect alignment. The black squares were just pieces of electrical tape.

title: Adjustable Drive Block Upgrade for Replicator 2 and 1

description.text:
An adjustable drive block for Replicator for experimental use. Via a knob fitted to a screw, the pressure of the axial bearing against the filament can be adjusted and fine-tuned.
This design does not need a metal spring and relies on the flexibility of the lever. Alternatively, it can use a rigid lever (supplied) and a small piece of rubber which is compressed by the M3 x 35 mm crew's tip.
Two different lever shapes are supplied for testing between flexible and rigid modes. By Creative Tools

  • Home - Things - GooglePlus - Twitter - Facebook - Youtube - Instructables - Instagram - Flickr - Vimeo - LinkedIn

Please note that this is an experimental design to test different and adjustable filament grip pressures. It is not evaluated to perform better or worse than the standard extruder block. For instructional images please see: http://flic.kr/s/aHsjHC7f6H
  • 3D print all the parts of this thing - preferably two sets. Use two shells and 30% to 40% infill.
  • Turn off your MakerBot Replicator and remove the power cord
  • Un-mount your current extruder stepper motor with its block
  • Unscrew the current block from the stepper motor
  • Remove the support material from the base plate
  • Cut a 4 mm long segment of an O-ring with roughly 3 mm width
  • Place the small rubber bit into the 3 mm hole of the base plate and press it firmly down into the bottom of the hole
  • Fix the base plate to the extruder with a small M3 x 6mm flat head cap screw
  • Place the axial ball bearing (4 x 10 x 4 mm) on the lever
  • Place the cover over the bearing and press it firmly to fit into the recession of the lever. If necessary, fix it with glue.
  • Insert an M3 Nylock nut, upside down, into the tip of the lever.
  • Place a drop of glue into the hole of the adjustment screw knob.
  • Insert the M3 x 35 mm screw into the knobs recession.
  • Glue the bottom part of the knob to fix the screw head in place
  • Let the glue set!
  • Insert the screw with the knob into the Nylock nut.
  • Place the lever with the bearing and adjustment screw onto the base plate.
  • Use an allen M3 x 16 mm to attach the lever to the base plate and stepper motor housing. Do not over-tighten!
  • Put a bit of filament into the extruder and adjust the knob to tighten the bearing against the filament and drive wheel.
  • Push and pull the filament and try different pressures to get a sense of how much pressure is optimal.
  • Place the stepper motor with its attached new block into the Replicator in the usual manner.
  • Turn on the power and put the Replicator on mode for loading filament.
  • When the temperature reaches 230 C, insert the filament through the drive block. Unscrew the knob so that the filament passes by the drive wheel with no effort.
  • You should now be able to manually extrude some plastic filament with the force of your fingers.
  • Tighten the knob until you feel that the drive wheel grips the filament and extrudes it by its own power.
  • Try different values to get experience.
  • Remember this is an experimental design!
  • Have fun! :)

    Rigid or flexible?

  • A rigid version of the lever is supplied if you want to try that.
  • To offer some flexibility or spring action, you can insert a small piece of rubber material into the small hole of the base plate where the tip of the adjustment screw sits.

    Need one?

    If you don't have your Replicator running or have access to the screws and bearing, get it at http://bit.ly/16bncdX

comments.text: Thanks for your suggestions and comments. It is totally true that M4 is much more common than M3. The reason for the latter though is that M3 (3 mm in diameter) is the standard thread already used in the four stepper motors. The adjustment screw does not need to be M3 and could easily be made differently.

author: kumru1998

title: X-Carve JTech Laser Mount with Fan Cooler / Exhaust

description.text:
This JTech laser holder for the X-Carve mounts in the DeWalt 611 spindle mount. Attach an 80mm fan to the top, then use the hose mount to attach a 3 or 4" dryer vent hose to carry the smoke and fumes to a ventilated area. It also acts as a cooler for the laser so you can run it longer at higher power levels! Since cooling and ventilation are a shared action in this mount you will need to clean the lens a bit more often. Some tips: 1) Mount the laser using small machine screws and nuts. Might require some modifications to get the laser beam perfectly straight.
2) Feed the laser cable through the hole in the size of the housing.
3) Attach 80mm fan to the top of the mount.
4) Attach the hose adapter to the top of the fan.
5) Gently push the laser mount into the spindle mount, leaving room for the laser's cable at the top of the mount. Be careful not to pinch the wire. Version 1.0 dated 2/23/2016 is a tight fit in the spindle mount, barely clearing the Z axis. You won't be moving the Z-axis much during engraving so Z clearance isn't a problem. 3/4/2016 - Uploaded pics of final build with a crazy Delta 130CFM fan attached. Find it on Amazon! It's amazingly strong so I will be adding PWM control to dial it in.
ToDo: Add better flange to hose adapter.

Printer:

XYZ Da Vinci

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

30-50%

Notes: I printed it with basic settings on the Da Vinci. Model seems strong at 30% infill 0.3mm layer height.

title: Diamond Hotend upgrade for Rebel II HD

description.text:
Complete set of printed parts for Rebel II HD 3D printer to be upgraded to Diamond Hotend with Compact Bowden Extruder or Geared Bowden Extruder. More photos here: https://onedrive.live.com/redir?resid=22C1FED0B09958D!3025&authkey=!AJq3CE3br11Nh8Q&ithint=folder%2cJPG List of required parts:
  • x axis carriage (1x)
  • updated diamond hotend cooler and shield blower (1x)
  • hotend cable holder with cable chain connector (1x),
  • left z axis column cable holder with cable chain connector (top and bottom parts) (1x)
  • cable chain pieces (36 x) (18 top, 18 bottom ones)
  • stepper expander mount (1x)
  • extender for filament holder (left 1x and right 1x)
  • filament holder wheels (4x)
  • cable mount (5x)
  • m6 T slot nut (3x)
  • fan blower (1x)
    • Compact Bowden Extruder
  • Compact extruder with integrated mount (3x)
    • or Geared Bowden Extruder
  • geared extruder motor mount (3x)
  • original Geared extruder parts (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:364734) (3x)
    • UPDATED 6.4.2017 Remixed Compact Bowden extruder improved. Bearing and idler are now mounted on both sides which allows for better pressure control.
    UPDATED: 19.9.2016 Remixed Compact Bowden extruder parts added. With this extruder construction I have got better final print results for 1.75 PLA.
    UPDATED: 31.12:2016 Added slightly remixed fan blower (printable without supports), improved left z axis column cable holder, extenders for filament holders (to be printable horizontaly without support)

Printer:

Rebel II HD

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes: Majority of parts does not require supports, but nr 6 and 12 need them. Part 11 should be printed without supports.
Used Win10 3D Builder app As it is not professional tool, would be happy to invite help with improving presented models. Some parts (e.g. extenders for filament holders definitely need it :-)

author: novotnyo

description.text:
This knob is modeled after those on my stove, but scaled down to 80% in order to fit better with the children's kitchen set for which this is intended. Will friction fit on 1/4" (6.35mm) shaft, in my case that of a potentiometer.
The knob has a nice feel to it and should be usable for many projects. The bottom has been left almost entirely hollow, instead relying on a few ribs for strength. It prints in about 35min on a Makerbot. If you want to print one for your stove, just scale it to 125% and adjust the bore, if 5/16" (8mm) won't fit. -Geert
Print. Enjoy.

title: Configurable spacer plate for NEMA stepper motors
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
You can use this configurable thing to make a spacer plate for NEMA (17) stepper motors.
The following parameters can be set: HEIGHT: Thickness of the plate.
BASE_SIZE: XY-dimension of the plate.
BASE_CHAMFER: Chamfer of the outer shape.
HOLE_DISTANCE: Distance of the mounting holes.
HOLE_DIAMETER: Diameter of the mounting hole.
FIT_DIAMETER: Diameter of the motor fit. If the height is lower than 5.0mm, no fit for the original mount is made.
The default values should fit for a NEMA 17 stepper motor. Values are taken from http://reprap.org/wiki/NEMA_17_Stepper_motor.

author: RomanBuchert

description.text: This is a tensile test specimen for testing any material you want to.

Objectives:
You can learn how to test materials under real circumstances.
Learn basic skills to use g code generators. Audiences:
There is no age limit to this project. Maybe the students should be 14 or older. Preparation:
You only need the things for a normal print Steps:
The students can design there own gcode with different characteristics (layer height, fill density, fill pattern, etc) after that they check there code with a tensile test. Results:
Students learn how test materials, how to use the g code generator software and they see which characteristics are important for a strong print (layer height, fill density, fill pattern, etc) Teachers and students can evaluate there gcodes by using a tensile test.

author: chev383

description.text:
12-6-16 update
I added a base plate that has enhanced reinforcement. I also attached a little camera mount that points face down if you want. There are also mounting places to attach front facing cameras. I have a gimbal mount for this quad but what I ran into is that it's too heavy for these 900kv motors. Here is a link to the gimbal if you want to attach a gimbal to your bigger drone.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1943377
the camera for the mount:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0148HVZIQ/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 March 25th update
parts will be coming in a few days I will be revising the base plate since I now understand how the quad flys and what would make it a better machine.
Also I will be updating the extending arms to be a bit thicker to hold up to crashes and such. With 920kv motors and 10 inch props this thing takes off like a rocket so it shouldn't be a problem weight wise.
The last thing to be edited will be the comm and top. I will be adding holes where zip ties are more useful and ended up drilling.
A new added part coming in a few days will be a light bar that will fit in the triangle holes on the arms. https://youtu.be/DCtqxmih5CE
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q_McspxJ7iw&feature=youtu.be I had the Idea 5 months ago to build a quadcopter completely from scratch out of ABS. It was a long journey and had its fair share of hickups, but I finally made it into the air. The frame is complete after many build attempts and is surprisingly really strong. It weighs in at about 1200 grams with all electronics, props, and motors. With 2x 2cell lipos in series it weighs about 1800 grams. The arms have the ability to fold towards the back for transportation which works out really well for the back seat of a car. I hope ya'll like it. Let me know if you have any questions, I'll be happy to answer. Sorry about the names of the files. Just follow the amount of each .stl and it'll all work out. Work in progress is just the legs which I will be adding later Supplies you will need for frame
-All M3 Bolts (16) 50mm, (8) 25mm, (10) 15mm screws for electronics
-Lots of ABS
-Patience
Supplies regarding electronics
-APM of any gen with anti vibration plate
-(4) 30a esc's
-(4) 950kv and below motors
-FPV gear
-12ga wire
-Radio receiver
-power distribution board

This is a mount to attach a generic solar phone charger (commonly found on eBay) to a backpack or messenger bag. This charger or any charger in a similar form factor should work fine. http://www.ebay.com/itm/Black-80000mAh-Dual-USB-Portable-Solar-Battery-Charger-Power-Bank-For-Cell-Phone-/141803317477?hash=item210422e8e5:g:I74AAOSwA4dWIJJ- You will also need four zip ties.

Notes: Hatchbox black 1.75mm PLA at 190°C -> 185°C with the printed bed at ~65°C.

Step 1 Hold the base plate in-place on the inside of a pocket (as seen in image 3). You may optionally use hot-glue to secure the plate to make this process easier. Step 2 Using a razer, cut three slots in the fabric of the pocket at each corner of the base plate. Step 3 Insert the solar charger into the mount, then snap the mount into the base plate. It may be necessary to remove more fabric from the middle slot in each corner in order for the mount to snap in. Note: mount the solar charger with the USB ports facing down. This will help protect it from rain; it is facing up in the above images for demonstration purposes only. Step 4 Secure all four corners of the mount to the base plate using zip ties. Insert one end on the zip tie through the outer-most loop of the base plate, thread it through the loop on the mount, then insert it through the inner-most loop of the base plate, and tie it.
This was designed in Autodesk Inventor 2016 and Blender 2.76.

This is an amazing sculpt by Razumnick. I found another remix of this sculpt with the text removed but the geometry was left a mess creating very strange infill patterns and cracks/holes. I have taken the original sculpt and re-processed the geo to make it water tight and have clean topology with the text removed.
Set at 130mm tall this should be much better to slice. I recommend manual supports to be added.

description.text: RC-Maul-Kupplung (Ef. Landmaschienen) die über einen Micro-Servo Geöffnet werden kann.

First of all this is NOT a traditional fish food feeder. It is a self-contained eco solution that flows like this:  fish food > booklice > fish
My fish food (flakes) tends to get moist in Singapore's humid weather, even with silica gel packs. That leads to booklice breeding in the thousands - but before you get squeamish, look it up. I used to throw out the food and get fresh packs only for this to reoccur before long. 
One day I fed my fishes some flakes WITH the booklice by mistake but to my surprise none died, in fact they loved it. Figuring this was a protein trade-up, I've been waiting for the li'l critters to crawl to the cap and (you guessed it) tap it to send them to a watery end.
Additionally I noticed they are so small they crawl out of a tightly sealed cap, so I started immersing the food bottle in a water dish. But I guess they don't understand water because everyday loads of them drown.
So, here is a simple holder that supports a small bottle of fish food (42.5mm dia) on the side of the tank (4.8mm glass) and the arm is submerged, so there is no way for the booklice to crawl out, except to feed the fishes automatically, as they feed on flake food.

This is version 2 of the Z-Axis Brace used to stablize the Z-wobble apparent in many printers. This one was designed for the Hictop Prusa i3 but should work on all or most i3 style printers with a 8mm thread and rod. The original design intended to have M8 nuts above and below the bearing, but this seemed unnecessary and took up too much space. It is better to have the bearing closer to the coupler, so the overall height has been lowered. This is the precise adjustment version so you can compensate for motor mounts that are not perfectly perpendicular to the build plate. Note
Funnily enough, I designed this part for M2 Nuts and Bolts but then realized I only had 2 of them on stock which is why there are only two in the picture :P

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Hictop Prusa i3 Aluminium

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

50%

Notes: Mirror the model to make the brace for the other side.

Additional Pieces Needed
  • Two standard bearings (one for each z-axis)
  • Three M2 Bolts with a minimum length of about 10-15mm
  • Three M3 Nuts
    • Installation 1.) Insert the M2 bolts into the brace 2.) Unscrew the stepper motors 3.) Put the bearing on the threaded rod, but tape it up to the x-carriage so that it is out of the way. (Optional: for extra stability, add an M8 Nyloc Nut above the bearing to keep pressure on the bearing and avoid the threaded rod grabbing the bearing.) 4.) Screw the stepper motors and brace on to the printer. 5.) Ensure everything is aligned and insert the threaded rods back into coupler as accurately as possible and secure them through the holes on the side of the brace.
    Note* It is important to get the z-wobble as low as possible before fixing the bearing to the brace to ensure optimal results. 6.) Insert the M2 Bolts into the brace and observe where the center of rotation is and slowly and incrementally tighten the bolts. (Optional: If you inserted an M8 Nyloc Nut earlier, lower it onto the bearing.) 7.) You are done installing the brace, now continue to level the X-Axis as per usual.

comments.text: Anyone else find it impossible to get a 608zz bearing onto the threaded rod? I love the design, but had to scrap using it since the bearing wouldn't fit. I even bought myself some decent ceramic ball bearings just for this, but I am sure I can find other uses for them if I can't get this part working.
